item.title: Agent-based modeling: Lizards & Rock, Paper, Scissors
item.description: Agent-based modeling Rock, paper, scissors Side Blotched Lizards Agent-based modeling Intro. Use/relevance in complexity economics. This article was inspired by this post, which I attempted to recreate and extend. Rock, paper, scissors Aim: Simulate simple rock, paper, scissors game to visualise a simple evolutionary process. Simple Game Rules: Individuals are organised on a lattice network. Each individual has a strategy (Rock, Paper, Scissors). Each time period we choose one individual at random to play a game.

item.title: A Field Guide to Lies & Stats (Levitin 2016)
item.description: Evaluating Numbers Plausibility Averages Axes Reporting How numbers are collected Probabilities Evaluating Words Identifying expertise Induction vs deduction Evaluating Numbers Plausibility Numerical sense checks. Claim: “In the 35 years since marijuana laws stopped being enforced in California, the number of marijuana smokers has doubled every year”. Even if we start with the most generous estimate that intitially there was 1 marijuana smoker then after 35 years that would give us \(2^{34} (> 17\text{bil})\) smokers.
